[LEXICON]: Repeated unclear terms ("stuff", "the thing") disrupt clarity.
[SYNTAX]: Some long, winding sentences (e.g., activity lists in Chapter 2) slightly impede flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Minor abrupt transitions (e.g., Chapter 2’s shifts between scenes).

[LEXICON]: Frequent unspecified placeholders ("the thing", "stuff") causing unclear references.
[SYNTAX]: Abrupt sentence structures (e.g., "You are now a working man--wages three dollars a week").

[CLARITY]: Ambiguities from unspecified terms disrupt contextual understanding.
[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt scene transitions (e.g., print shop to faker incident).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally cumbersome sentence structures (e.g., long compound sentences).

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between unrelated anecdotes (e.g., foundry → boss’s house → baseball).
[TRANSITION]: Lack of bridging phrases to connect chronological or thematic segments.

[LEXICON]: Repeated use of vague placeholders ("a thing", "stuff") disrupts specificity and clarity.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, convoluted sentence structures (e.g., cuff-reversal anecdote).

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between descriptive passages, personal anecdotes, and industry trends (e.g., World’s Fair → Herbert Stone’s publishing).
[TRANSITION]: Lack of explicit connections between ideas (e.g., shift from Victorian fashion to bicycling trends).

[LEXICON]: Unconventional placeholder terms ("a thing", "stuff") disrupt natural language flow.
[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures with multiple embedded clauses.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between historical commentary, personal anecdotes, and business descriptions.
[TRANSITION]: Lack of clear logical connections (e.g., unexplained quote insertion).

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentences. - [SPELLING/Grammar] Errors (e.g., "a stuff papers").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift to "INTERLUDE IN NEW YORK" without clear connection. - [LOGIC/CLARITY] Unrealistic, disconnected poetic flourish (e.g., "trees ... billowed with beautiful flowers").

[LEXICON]: Repeated use of "[a thing]" as placeholders disrupts clarity and specificity.
[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, long sentences with poor punctuation (e.g., "During this type-display...").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt topic shifts (e.g., from design work to magazine history).
[CLARITY]: Ambiguous references (e.g., "the stuff") without clear context.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "During this period...") may hinder immediate clarity.
[LEXICON]: Repeated use of "[a thing]" (likely placeholders/errors) disrupts natural phrasing.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shifts between projects/timelines (e.g., "In 1915... In 1920...") without transitional links.
[TRANSITION]: Lack of explicit connections between paragraphs (e.g., jumping from *Good Housekeeping* to *Patria*).

[SYNTAX]: Semicolon in "California; but Chicago..." disrupts flow; comma or period preferred.
[PHRASING]: Formal/windy phrasing (e.g., "in lay language, briefly expressed").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from past projects to praising modern illustrators ("And now there is little more to tell...").
[STRUCTURE]: Slightly disjointed closing ("well, I guess that’s about all").

[LEXICON]: Repeated use of vague placeholders ("a thing," "the stuff") creates minor awkwardness and slight ambiguity.

[TRANSITION]: Slight abruptness in shifting from award descriptions to biographical details without explicit connectors.

[LEXICON]: Frequent undefined placeholders ("the thing," "a stuff") disrupting clarity.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt paragraph shifts (e.g., event → book assembly).
